DIV1.P: THE CONTRIVANCES; OR, More Ways than One. As it is Acted at the THEATRE-ROYAL IN DRURY-LANE.
LONDON: Printed for W. Mears at the Lamb, and J. Brown at the Black Swan, both without Temple-Bar. MDCCXV. [Price 6d.]

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P:
WELL! tho' Pimping is the most honourable and profitable of all Profes∣sions, it is certainly the most dangerous and fa∣tiguing; but of all Fa∣tigues, there's none like following a vir∣tuous Mistress—There's not one Letter I carry, but I run the Risque of kick∣ing, caning, or pumping, nay often hang∣ing—Let me see, I have committed three Burglaries already to get one Letter to her—Now if my Master shou'd not get the Gyp∣sy
at last, I have ventur'd my sweet Person to a fair Purpose: He has nothing left but the Name of Captain and his Half Pay; which is as much as to say, that I his faith∣ful Servant, and so forth, must come off with no Pay, or trust 'till Dooms-day—My Pockets are so empty, that old Nick may securely dance there, for there's not one Cross left to frighten him away—Ah! it was not so in Flanders, when the French Wine and French Mony tumbled a∣bout as if it wou'd never be Night—But Basta! here comes my Master and his Friend Mr. Hearty—I must haste and get our Disguises—
SP.L: And if Dame Fortune fails us now (to win her)
I'll say no more, but think the Devil's in her.

SP.SPEAKER: Hear.
SP.P: Why so melancholly, Captain? Come, come, a Man of your Gaiety and Courage shou'd never take a Disappointment so to Heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Rove.
SP.P:
'Sdeath, to be prevented when I had brought my Design so near Perfection! an old subtle cross-grain'd Hunks—But have her I must and will, or I am resolv'd
to burn the old Drone out of his Hive, and carry the Hony-comb away in Triumph.

SP.SPEAKER: Hear.
SP.P: A very consciencious Resolution truly—But, Captain, wou'd you be less open and daring in your Attempts, you might hope to succeed—The old Gentleman, you know, is cautious to a Degree; his Daughter is under a strict Confinement; and wou'd you use more of the Fox than the Lion, Fortune may perhaps throw an Op∣portunity in your Way—But you must have Patience.

SP.SPEAKER: Rove.
SP.P: Who can have Patience when Dan∣ger's so near? Read this Letter, and tell me then what Room there is for Patience.

LETTER.P: To Morrow will prevent all our vain Strug∣gles to get to each other—I am then to be marry'd to my eternal Aversion—You know the Fop, it is Cuckoo, who having a large Estate, is forc'd upon me; but my Heart can be none but Rovewell's—Immediately after the Receipt of this, meet Betty at the old Place: There is yet one In∣vention left; if you pursue it closely, you may perhaps release me, who wou'd be your Arethusa.

SP.SPEAKER: Rove.
SP.P: Yes, Arethusa, I will release thee or dye in the Attempt. Dear Friend, ex∣cuse my Rudeness, you know the Reason.

SP.SPEAKER: Hear.
SP.P: Well, go thy Ways and get her, for thou deserv'st her—I find a Soldier's never idle—as soon as he has done with his Enemy he attacks his Mistress, and sel∣dom fails to conquer.
SP.L: When true-bred English Courage takes the Field,
The Frenchmen and the Ladies quickly yield.
See! smiling Cynthia, now begins to rise,
And add transparent Glories to the Skies.
Hail beauteous Rival of the dark some Night,
Whose Glooms give way to thy superior Light!
Thy lucid Charms afford a second Day,
And guide the weary Pilgrim in his Way.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Pray, Daughter, what Linguo is that same that you sputter out at this Rate?

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.P: English, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: English, quotha'! adad, I took it for Nonsence.

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.P: 'Tis an Hymn to the Moon.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: A Hymn to the Moon! a Hymn to the Devil, you Jade you—I'll have none of your Hymns in my House—Give me the Book, Mistress?

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.P: I hope, Sir, there's no harm in reading a harmless Poem.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Give me the Book, I say, Huswife—Poems with a Pox, what are they good for? But to blow up the fire of Love, and make young Wenches as hot as the De∣vil—but I have taken care of you, Mistress, for to Morrow you shall have a Husband to stay your Stomach, and no less a Person than Squire Cuckoo.

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.P: You will not be so cruel to marry me to a Man I cannot love?

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: But you must and shall love him, Huswife: What! you hone after a red Rag, I warrant you: Nothing less than a Captain will go down with you, forsooth; a dis∣banded Captain—Such a Fellow deserves Twelve Thousand Pounds to squander away, does he? But I have put a Spoke in his Wheel—for to Morrow you shall be bound Apprentice for Life, and then your disbanded Lover may e'en hang himself.

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.P: For Heav'n's sake, dear Sir, give me a little time to consider: Marriage is a Con∣cern of the utmost Consequence—put it off for one Month, that I may endea∣vour to make my Duty and Desires go to∣gether.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Do you your Duty, and a Fig for Desires—No, no, Mistress; Delays are dangerous in these Cases—Mr. Cuckoo is a brisk young Fellow, and a little Fea∣ther-bed Doctrine will soon put the Cap∣tain out of your Head—and to put you out of his Power, you shall be given over to the Squire to Morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.P: Pray, Sir, consider—put it off for a Week, let me have time to make the ne∣cessary Preparations.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: What, to run away with the Cap∣tain, Mistress?—no, no, to Morrow is the Day.

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.P: Surely you will at least defer it one Day?

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P:
No, nor one Hour—to Mor∣row Morning at eight of the Clock precise∣ly—In the mean time, take Notice that the Squire's Sister is hourly expected, a good plain Country Girl, but a great For∣tune—I believe it will be a Match between her and your Cousin Frank—the old Folks have almost agreed about the
Matter—so pray do you be civil and sociable with her, and let me have none of your Pouts and Louts, as you tender my Displeasure.

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.P: To Morrow is but short Warning—but we may be too cunning for you yet, old Gentleman.
O Betty! welcome a thousand times over, What News—have you seen the Captain, Betty?

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: Yes, Madam, and if you were to see him in his new Rigging, you'd split your Sides with laughing—such a Hoyden, such a piece of Country Stuff, you never set your Eyes on—but the Petticoats are soon thrown off, and if good Luck at∣tends us, you may soon conjure Miss Mal∣kin, the Squire's Sister, into your own dear Captain.

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.P: But when will he come?

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P:
Instantly, Madam, he only stays to settle Matters for our Escape, he's in deep Consultation with his privy Counsellor Ro∣bin, who is to attend him in the Quality of a Country Putt—They'll both be here in a Moment, so let's in and pack up the Jew∣els, that we may be ready at once to leap
into the Saddle of Liberty, and ride full speed to your Desires.

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.P: Dear Betty, let's make haste, I think every Moment an Age 'till I'm free from this Bondage.
SP.L: When Parents obstinate and cruel prove,
And force us to a Man we cannot Love,
'Tis fit we disappoint the sordid Elves,
And wisely get us Husbands for our selves.

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: There they are—in, in.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: You're woundy hasty methinks, to knock at that rate—this is certainly some Courtier come to borrow Mony, I know it by the sawcy rapping of the Foot∣man—Who's at the Door?

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Tummos! who's Tummos? Who wou'd you speak with, Friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: With young Master's Vaather-in-Law that mun be, Mr. Hardguts.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: And what's your Business with Mr. Hardguts?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P:
Why young Mistress is come out o'
the Country, to see Brother's Wife that mun be, that's all.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Odso; the Squire's Sister—I'm sorry I made 'em wait so song.
SP.STAGE: Enter Rovewell drest like a Country Gentle∣woman, and Robin like a Country Clown.
SP.P: Save you fair Lady, you're welcome to Town: [Salutes him.] A very modest come∣ly Maiden truly. How long have you been in Town, Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: Why an Hour and a bit, or so—we just put up our Horses at King's-Arms yonder, and staid a crum to zee poor things feed or so, for your London Ostlers give lit∣tle enough to poor Beasts, and you stond not by 'em your zel, and zee 'em fed, they'll cheat you to your Face.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg
SP.P: Why how now Clodpate? Are you to speak before your Mistress? With your Hat on too? Is that your Country breed∣ing?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P:
Why an it's on, it's on, an it's off, it's off—what cares Tummos? for your false-hearted London Compliments—an you'd have an answer from young Mi∣stress, you mun look to Tummos—for she's so main bashful, she never speaks one
Word but her Prayers, and thosen so softly that no Body can hear her.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: I like her the better—for Si∣lence is a heav'nly Virtue in a Woman—but very rare to be found in this wicked Place—Have you seen your Brother, pretty Lady, since you came to Town? [Rovewell Curtsies.] O miraculous Mode∣sty! wou'd all Women were thus? Can't you speak, Madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: An you get a Word from her, 'tis more than she has spoken to us these four∣score and seven long Miles—but young Mistress will prate fast enough an you set her amongst your Women Volk, or so, when she's once acquainted.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg
SP.P: Say'st thou so, honest Fellow, then I'll send her to those that have Tongue e∣nough I'll warrant you—Here Betty.
Take this young Lady to my Daughter, 'tis Squire Cuckoo's Sister; and d'ye hear? make much of her, I charge you.

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: Yes, Sir—please to follow me, Madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Well honest Friend, and where's the Squire?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: Why one cannot find a Mon out in this same London, there are so many Ta∣veruns and Chockling-Housen, you may as well seek a Needle in a Hay Fardel, as they sayn in the Country—I was at Squire's Lodging yonder, and there was no body, but a prate a pace whorson of a Footboy, and he told me Maister was at Chockling-House, and the while the Vixen did nothing but taunt and laugh at me, or so—I Cod I cou'd have found in my Heart to have given a good wherrit i'th' Chops, so I cou'd—so I went to one Chockling-House, and Squire was not there, and so I went to t'other Chockling-House, and t'other, 'till I was a weary, and I cou'd see nothing but a many People supping hot Suppings, and reading your Gazate Papers so we came away here and please you, but we had much ado to find out your Worship's House, the vixen Boys set us a thick a side, and a thack a side, that we were almost lost—an it were not for an honest Fellow that came and show∣ed us the right way.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: It's a pity they shou'd use Strangers so—but as to your young Mistress, does she never speak?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: Adod, Sir, never to a Mon, why she wo'not speak to her own Father, she's so main bashful or so—

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: That's strange indeed—but how does my Friend Sir Roger?—he's well, I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: Hearty still, Sir—he has drunk down six Fox-hunters sin last Lammas—he holds old course still; twenty Pipes a Day, a Cup of Mum in the Morning, a Tankard of Ale at Noon, and three Bot∣tles of Stingo at Night—the same Mon now he was thirty Years ago, or so.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Good now, good now! but wou'dst drink, honest Friend?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: I don't care an I do a bit or so, for to tell you the truth, I'm main dry.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Here, John.
Take this honest Fellow down, and make him welcome—when your Mistress is ready to go, we'll call you.

These Country Fellows are very blunt, but very honest—I wou'd fain hear his Mi∣stress talk—he said she'd find her Tongue when she was amongst those of her own Sex—I'll go listen for once, and hear what the young Tits have to say to one another.

SP.SPEAKER: Rove.
SP.P: Dear Arethusa! delay not the time thus—your Father will certainly come in, and surprize us.

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: Let's make Hay while the Sun shines, Madam, I long to be out of this Prison.

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.P: So do I, but not on the Captain's Conditions, to be his Prisoner for Life.

SP.SPEAKER: Rove.
SP.P: I shall run mad if you trifle thus—name your Conditions—I sign my consent before-hand

SP.SPEAKER: Arg. listning.]
SP.P: So, so, this is as it shou'd be—they are as gracious as can be already—how the young Tit smuggles her—adod, she kisses with a hearty good Will.

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.P: O the great Romp, he takes one's Breath away—how cou'd you pass upon my Father? I never saw such a hoyden mas∣culine Monster in my Life.

SP.SPEAKER: Rove.
SP.P: Let's once get out I'll tell you the whole Story—this is no Time or Place for Particulars—if you lov'd me, or valu'd your own Happiness, you wou'd not trifle away this Opportunity.

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.P: Indeed Captain, I'm afraid to trust you.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Captain! how's this—bless my Eye-sight—I know the Villain now, but I'll be even with him.

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: Dear, dear Madam, don't trifle so, I long to see you both between a pair of Sheets—the Parson's at the very next Door, you'll be tackt together in the twinkling of a Bedstaff, and then I'll trust you to come back to your Cage again, if you can do it with a safe Conscience.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Here's a treacherous Jade! I'll do your Business for you, Mrs. Jezabel.

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: Consider, Madam, what a Life you lead here, what a jealous, ill-natur'd, watch∣ful, covetous, barbarous, obstinate old Cuff of a Father you have to deal with—what a glorious Opportunity this is? And what a sad, sad, very sad thing it is, to die a Maid.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: A Whore, I cou'd slit her Nose.

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: In short, Madam, if you stay much longer, you may repent it every Vein in your Heart—the old Hunks will undoubt∣edly pop in upon us, and discover all, and then we're undone for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: You may be damn'd for ever, Mrs. Impudence.

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.P: Well, Captain, if you shou'd de∣ceive me—

SP.SPEAKER: Rove.
SP.P: If I do, may Heav'n—

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.P: Nay, no swearing Captain, for fear you shou'd break your Oath.

SP.SPEAKER: Rove.
SP.P: How can you doubt me, Arethusa, when you know how much I love—

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Ah wheedling Dog! but I'll spoil his Sport anon.

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: Come, come away, dear Madam—I have the Jewels—but stay, I'll go first to see if the Coast be clear.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Where are you going, pretty Maiden?

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: Only do—do—down Stairs, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: And what hast thou got there, Child?

SP.SPEAKER: Bet.
SP.P: Nothing but Pi—Pi—Pins, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P:
Here, give me the Pins—and do you go to Hell, Mrs. Minx, d'ye hear? Out of my House this Minute, or expect the dreadful Issue of my righteous Indigna∣tion. [Thrusts her out.] O Tempora! O Mo∣res! what an Age is this? Get you in for∣sooth, I'll talk with you anon—So, Captain, are those your Regimental Cloaths? I'll as∣sure you they become you mightily, if you did but see your self now, how much like a Hero you look. [Laughs.] But, Cap∣tain, an't you an impudent Dog now, an't
you?—must no Body serve your Turn but my Daughter? nothing less than twelve thousand Pounds? Well, I find you Soldiers rate your selves high—but you deserve it in Truth: you work your Brains, you try Stratagems, you transform into a thousand Shapes to catch a Fortune—Ecce Signum, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Rove.
SP.P: 'Sblood and Fury, stop your Grin∣ning, or I'll stretch your Mouth with a Vengeance.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Nay, nay, Captain Bellswagger, if you're so passionate it's high time to call Aid and Assistance: Here Richard, Thomas, John, help me to lay hold on this Fellow; you have no Sword now, Captain, no Sword, d'ye mark me, ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Rove.
SP.P: But I have a Pistol, Sir, at your Ser∣vice.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: O Lord! O Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: Rove.
SP.P: And I'll unload it in your Breast, if you stir one Step after me.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: A bloody-minded Dog.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P:
And see here, Gentlemen, here are two little Bull-dogs of the same Breed, they are wonderful Scowrers of the Brain—So that if you offer to molest or follow us—
you understand me, Gentlemen, you under∣stand me.

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Serv.
SP.P: Yes, yes, we understand you with a Pox.

SP.SPEAKER: 2d Serv.
SP.P: The Devil go with 'em, I say.

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: O Lord! O Lord!

SP.SPEAKER: 1st Serv.
SP.P: Indeed, Sir, we did not fol∣low you, we didn't indeed, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rove.
SP.P: D'ye hear, old Gentleman, I'll have your Daughter, if I wade to her thro' the Blood of you and your whole Generati∣on; and so good-bye t'ye, old Goose-Cap.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Ay, ay, good-bye t'ye in the Devil's Name—a terrible Dog! What a Fright he has put me in! I shan't be my self this Month—And you, ye cowardly Ra∣scals, to stand by and see my Life in Dan∣ger—Get out, ye Slaves, out of my House I say.

What a murthering Son of a Whore is this? but I'll prevent him—he shall eat Brick, and Stone, and Iron to get at her again, I'll warrant him—But to Morrow she shall be marry'd certainly, and then my furious Gentleman can have no Hopes left—A Jezabel, to love a
Red-Coat without any Money—Had he but Money, if he wanted Sense, Man∣ners, or even Manhood itself, it matter'd not a Pin—but to want Mony is the Devil—Well, I'll secure her under Lock and Key 'till to Morrow; and if her Husband can't keep her from Captain∣hunting, e'en let her bring him home a fresh Pair of Horns every time she goes out up∣on the Chase.

DIV1.STAGE: Arethusa sitting melancholly on a Couch, enter to her Argus.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P:
So Lady, you're welcome home—See how the pretty Turtle sits moaning the Loss of her Mate—What, not a Word, Thusy! not a Word, Child! Come, come, don't be in the Dumps so, and I'll fetch the Captain, or the Squire's Sister, perhaps they may make it prattle a bit. Ah, ungracious Huswife! is all my Care come to this? Is this the Gratitude you shew to your Uncle's Memory! to throw away (what he bustled so hardly for) at so mad a Rate! Did he leave you twelve thousand Pounds, think you, to make you no better
than a Soldier's Trull, to follow a Camp, to carry a Knapsack? This is what you'd have, Mistress, is it not?

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.P: This, or ten thousand times worse, were better with the Man I love, than to be chain'd to the nauseous Embraces of one I hate.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Very well, Mrs. Termagant, very well! this is the way you answer your Fa∣ther, is it?

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.P: You never found me guilty of this Language, Sir, 'till now your Usage forc'd me to it—My Uncle left my Porti∣on entirely at my own Disposal, knowing your Covetousness wou'd prompt you to force me against my Inclinations—Mr. Cuckoo is a Fop, whose Affectation and Ignorance I abhor—Captain Rovewell has Merit, Sense, and Courage—I love him, and can be happy in no other, and no other will I have.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: So! so! very pretty! very pretty indeed! I tell you, Mrs. Snapdragon, you shall have Squire Cuckoo, and no other, or the Devil a Penny shall you have of mine; mark that.

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.P:
My Uncle, Sir, has left me enough to make my self happy; and you are free to dispose of your own as you please—
but me you never shall against my Inclina∣tions.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: A very dutiful Lady indeed! I'll make you sing another Song to Morrow, Mistress; and 'till then I'll leave you in Salvâ Custodiâ to consider—bye Thu∣sy.

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.P: How barbarous is the Covetousness and Caution of ill-natur'd Parents; they toil for Estates to make Posterity happy, and then by mistaken Prudence they match us to our Aversion—Thus while they measure Happiness by Riches, they only seek to make their Children misera∣rable—But I am resolv'd not to suf∣fer tamely however—They shall find, tho' my Body's weak, my Resolution's strong; and I may yet find Spirit enough to plague 'em.
SP.L: Sooner than I'll forego the Man I prize,
I'll brave 'em, tho' I fall a Sacrifice.

SP.SPEAKER: Hear.
SP.P: O' my Conscience I think this young Fellow will run mad—So many Enterprizes and Disappointments upon the Back of each other shou'd pall him me∣thinks—but yet he holds out couragiously, and is still as vigorous as ever—What he is upon now I know not, but he swears he'll carry her—I wish he is not balk'd, for the old Fellow is more upon his Guard now than ever.

How have I been deceiv'd in this Boy! I find him the very Reverse of what his Step∣mother represented him—and am now sen∣sible it was only her ill Usage that forc'd my Child away—His not having seen me since he was five Years old renders me a perfect Stranger to him—under that Pre∣tence I have got into his Acquaintance, and find him all I cou'd wish—Here he comes, big with another Plot—but if it fails, I believe my Mony must buy him the Girl at last.

SP.SPEAKER: Rove.
SP.P: So, my dear Friend here already; this is kind.
SP.STAGE: [Draws his Sword, and makes a Signal.
SP.P: Is your Mistress lock'd up, say you?

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, and Betty's turn'd away, and all the Men Servants; and there's no living Soul in the House but our old Cookmaid, and I, and my Master, and Mrs. Thusy, and she cries, and cries, and cries her Eyes out almost.

SP.SPEAKER: Rove.
SP.P: O the tormenting News! If the Garrison is so weak, the Castle may be the sooner storm'd—But how did you get out?

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: Thro' the Kitchin-Window, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rove.
SP.P: Shew me the Window presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: Alack-a-day, it won't do indeed, Sir, that Plot won't take.

SP.SPEAKER: Rove.
SP.P: Why, Sirrah?

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: You are something too big, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rove.
SP.P: I'll try that however.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: Indeed, Sir, you can't get your Leg in, but I cou'd put you in the Way.

SP.SPEAKER: Rove.
SP.P: How, dear Boy!

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: I can lend you the Key of Mrs. Thusy's Chamber—if you can contrive to get in∣to the House—but you must be sure to let my Mistress out.

SP.SPEAKER: Rove.
SP.P: How coud'st thou get it? This is almost a Miracle.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: I pick'd it out of my Master's Coat-Pocket, Sir, this Morning, when I was a brushing him.

SP.SPEAKER: Rove.
SP.P: That's my Boy—there, there's Mony for you.

SP.SPEAKER: Boy.
SP.P: My Master will miss me, Sir, I must go, but I wish you good Luck.

SP.SPEAKER: Rove.
SP.P: So my Hearts of Oak, are you all ready?

SP.SPEAKER: All.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, yes, and it please your no∣ble Honour.

SP.SPEAKER: Rove.
SP.P: You know your Cue then—Serjeant to your Post.
SP.STAGE: [Places the Soldiers out of sight, then knocks loud.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: What, are you all asleep, and dead, in this House, that they can't hear one knock?

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: You are very hasty, Sir, methinks.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: My Business, Sir, requires haste!

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Your Business! pray what is your Business, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: My Business, Sir, is to borrow a thousand Pound of you.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Very concise indeed! but upon what Security, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: Upon what Security! upon my own, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Sir, your most humble Servant, you must excuse me, I don't lend Mony at that rate—a thousand Pound upon thy Security, ha, ha, ha, didst ever see a thousand Pence of thy own—pray, Sir, what Countryman are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: 'Sdeath, Sir, do you mean to affront me?

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: O by no means, Sir; only to shut the Door, and keep the thousand Pound to my self.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: Sir, I must have Satisfaction.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Get you gone Fellow, you want to rob me, do you?

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: 'Sblood, and Fire, and Fury!
SP.STAGE:
[Lays hold of him, and pulls him out of the House, the Soldiers seize him, blind∣fold
him, and gag him, and stand o∣ver him with drawn Swords: Robin and Captain go in and bring out Are∣thusa, and carry her off—then the Soldiers ungag Argus, and run off.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Thieves, Thieves.

SP.SPEAKER: Mob.
SP.P: What's the matter, what's the mat∣ter!

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: O Neighbours I'm robb'd, and mur∣ther'd, ruin'd and undone for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Mob.
SP.P: Why what's the matter, Master?

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: There's a whole Legion of Thieves in my House, they gagg'd me, and blind∣folded me, and offer'd forty naked Swords at my Breast—I beg of you to assist me, or they'll strip the House in a Minute.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Mob.
SP.P: Forty drawn Swords, say you, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Ay, and more I think on my Con∣science.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Mob.
SP.P: Then look ye, Sir, I am a mar∣ry'd Man, and have a Family, and I wou'd not venture amongst such a parcel of Blood∣thirsty Rogues for the World; but if you please, I'll run and call a Constable.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.P: Ay, ay, call a Constable, call a Constable.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg,
SP.P: I shan't have a Penny left, if we stay for a Constable—I am but one Man, and as old as I am, I'll lead the way if you'll follow me.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.P: Ay, ay, in, in, follow, follow, Huzzi!

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Mob.
SP.P: Prithee Jack do you go in, and see what's the matter?

SP.SPEAKER: 3 Mob.
SP.P: Nay, do you go in, and you come to that.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Mob.
SP.P: I go in, what shou'd I go in for? I have lost nothing.

SP.SPEAKER: Wom.
SP.P: What, no body to help the poor old Gentleman? If I was a Man l'd follow him my self.

SP.SPEAKER: 3 Mob.
SP.P: Why don't you then? What oc∣casion have I to be kill'd for him, or you either, ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.P: Here's Mr. Constable, here's Mr. Constable.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Silence, in the King's Name.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.P: Ay, Silence, Silence!

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: What's the meaning of this Riot, who makes all this Disturbance?

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Mob.
SP.P: I'll tell you, Mr. Constable.

SP.SPEAKER: 3 Mob.
SP.P: And please your Worship, let me speak.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Ay, this Man talks like a Man of Parts—What's the matter, Friend?

SP.SPEAKER: 3 Mob.
SP.P: And please your noble Worship's Honour, we are his Majesty's Liege Sub∣jects, and were terrified out of our Habita∣tions and dwelling Places by a Cry from a∣broad; which your noble Worship must understand was occasionable by the Gentle∣man of this Houfe, who was so unfortuna∣ble as to be kill'd by Thieves, who are now in his House to the Numbration of above sorty, and please your Worship, all com∣pleatly arm'd with Powder and Ball—Backswords, Pistols, Bayonets, and Blunder∣busses.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: But what is to be done in this Case?

SP.SPEAKER: 3 Mob.
SP.P: Why and please your Worship, knowing your noble Honour to be the King's Majesty's noble Officer of the Peace—we thought 'twas best your Honour shou'd come and terrifie these Rogues a∣way with your noble Authority.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P:
Well said, very well said indeed—Gentlemen, I am the King's Officer, and I command you in the King's Name to aid and assist me to call them Rogues out of the House—Who's within there? I Charge you come out in the King's Name,
and submit your selves to my Royal Au∣thority.

SP.SPEAKER: 2 Mob.
SP.P: This is the Gentleman that was kill'd, and please your Worship.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: O Neighbours! I am ruin'd and un∣done for ever—they have taken away all that's dear to me in the World.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Mob.
SP.P: That's his Mony—'tis a sad covetous Dog.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Why what's the matter? What have they done?

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: O they have taken my Child from me, my Thusa.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Good lack!

SP.SPEAKER: 3 Mob.
SP.P: Marry come up—what Valua∣tion can she be—but have they taken no∣thing else?

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Would they had stript my House of every Pennyworth, so they had left my Child.

SP.SPEAKER: 1 Mob.
SP.P: That's a Lie, I believe—for he loves his Mony beyond his Soul, and wou'd sooner part with that, than a Groat.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: This is the Captain's doings—but I'll have him hang'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: But where are the Thieves?

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Gone, gone, beyond all hopes of pursuit.

SP.SPEAKER: 3 Mob.
SP.P: What, are they gone then—come, Neighbours, let's go in, and kill eve∣ry Mother's Child of 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Con.
SP.P: Hold, I charge you to commit no Murderation—follow me, and we'll ap∣prehend 'em.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Go Villains, Cowards, Cuckolds, Scoundrels, or I shall suspect you are the Thieves that mean to rob me of what is yet left—how brave you are now the Danger's over—

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Bless me! who have we got here? O Thusy! Thusy! I had rather never have seen thee again, than to have found thee in such Company.

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.P: Sir, I hope my Husband's Company is not criminal.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Your Husband! who's your Hus∣band? Huswife? That Scoundrel, that No-Captain—out of my sight thou ungracious Wretch—I'll go make my Will this Mi∣nute—and you you Villain, how dare you look me in the Face after this? I'll have you hang'd; I will, Sirrah.

SP.SPEAKER: Hear.
SP.P: O fie, Brother Argus, moderate your Passion—you don't do well to abuse your Son-in-Law at this rate—It ill be∣comes the Friendship you owe Ned Worthy, to villifie and affront his only Child, and for no other Crime than improving that Friendship which has ever been between us.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Ha! my dear Friend alive! I heard thou wer't dead in the Indies: And is that thy Son! and my Godson if I am not mi∣staken!

SP.SPEAKER: Hear.
SP.P: The very same—the last and best Remains of our Family—forc'd by my Wife's Cruelty and my Absence to the Army—my Wife is since dead, and the Son she had by her first Husband, whom she intended to Heir my Estate—but Fortune guided me by Chance to my dear Boy, who after twenty Years absence, and changing my Name, knew me not—'till I just now discover'd my self to him, and your fair Daughter, whom I will make him deserve by thirty thousand Pound, which I brought from India—beside what Estate I may leave him at my Death.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P:
And to match that, old Boy—my Daughter shall have every Penny of mine, besides her Uncle's Legacy. Ah you young Rogue! had I known you before, I wou'd
not have us'd you so roughly—but now you have won my Girl so bravely, take her and welcome—but you must excuse all Faults—the old Man meant all for the best—you must not be angry.

SP.SPEAKER: Capt.
SP.P: Sir, on the contrary, we ought to beg your Pardon for the many Disquiets we have given you—and with your Pardon, we hope for your Blessing.

SP.SPEAKER: Rob.
SP.P: Sir, I hope you'll forgive me too, for truly, Sir, if my Master's Necessity had not oblig'd me to it, I had never troubled your Worship for a thousand Pound at once, but the next time I do (being you doubted my Word) I'll give you my Bond for the Payment.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: And I'll give you my Bond that you shall be hang'd if you do. But I'll forgive you, you Rogue, tho' you don't deserve it, Sir∣rah—Well, bless you both my dear Chil∣dren—ah the little Rogues, how pretty they look—come, buss and Friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Hear.
SP.P: Heavn's bless you together—now old School-fellow, what say'st to a Grand∣son?

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Ay, that wou'd be somewhat indeed—but who doubts it—the young Rogue looks vigorous, he has it in him, I'll war∣rant him: But, Brother Worthy, how cam'st alive again?—I heard for a Certainty you were dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Hear.
SP.P: I was very near Death, 'tis true—but Fortune protected me—every Ship in the Fleet was lost but mine—which tho' it was deeply laden, escaped, and brought me Home safe with a Cargo, worth thirty thousand Pounds, which shall be settled on my Boy to Morrow.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: My Thusy, Sir, shan't be behind hand—But Hussy, what makes you in such a brown Study? Why don't you kiss your old Father—adod, I am so transported, I can't tell whether I'm alive or dead.

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.P: May your Joy be everlasting.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: It will, you Jade,—Come Son, you must make my House your own—for the future: Brother Worthy, you shall lodge here too: Come, let's in.

DIV1.L: In vain we strive to force a Woman's Will:
Do what we can, they'll get the better still.
